steady_state.title: The Steady State (Late Reproductive)
steady_state.cycle_description: Periods are regular, but the cycle may shorten by 2-3 days (e.g., from 28 to 25 days).
steady_state.neuro_science: Ovarian reserve begins to decline. The brain works harder to signal the ovaries, leading to early spikes in Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH).

ui_markup.main_message:
Your brain is working harder to maintain balance;
this is the time to establish your health baseline.

early_transition.title: The Great Fluctuation (Early Transition)
early_transition.cycle_description: A persistent difference in cycle length (7+ days difference between consecutive cycles).
early_transition.neuro_science: The onset of "true" perimenopause. Estrogen is no longer declining smoothly; it fluctuates wildly, often causing "estrogen dominance" symptoms like irritability or breast tenderness.

ui_markup.main_message:
Wild estrogen fluctuations may lead to mood shifts
as your system begins its transition.

late_transition.title: The Gap (Late Transition)
late_transition.cycle_description: 60 days or more without a period, or skipping multiple cycles entirely.
late_transition.neuro_science: The Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Ovarian (HPO) axis is "powering down." This is the peak "window of vulnerability" for the brain's thermostat (the hypothalamus) as it loses its steady estrogen supply.

ui_markup.main_message:
Sleep disruptions and hot flashes are common as the
hypothalamus adjusts to changing estrogen levels.

early_postmenopause.title: The Milestone (Early Postmenopause)
early_postmenopause.cycle_description: It has been 12+ consecutive months since your last period (Years 1–5 post-FMP).
early_postmenopause.neuro_science: You have reached the official milestone of menopause. The brain and body are actively adapting to a new, lower-estrogen baseline.

ui_markup.main_message:
Your body is recalibrating to a lower estrogen state,
shifting focus toward metabolic and bone health.

late_postmenopause.title: The New Plateau (Late Postmenopause)
late_postmenopause.neuro_science: Beginning roughly 5-8 years after your final period, the endocrine system stabilizes. While hot flashes typically subside, the focus shifts to long-term "somatic" health—protecting the brain, bones, and cardiovascular system.

ui_markup.main_message:
With the endocrine system stabilized, the focus turns
to long-term vitality and cognitive preservation.
